question: Question_01_(e)
statement:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

\[\displaystyle
p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4\]

\textbf{(e)} Write down the MATLAB/OCTAVE code that plots the points
\emph{(0,1)}, \emph{(1,2)} and \emph{(2,2)} and the polynomial
\emph{p(x)} that

(i) has zero slopes at \emph{x = 0} and \emph{x = 2},

(ii) comes closest in the least square sense to passing through the
points \emph{(0,1)}, \emph{(1,2)} and \emph{(2,2)}.
hints:
In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2012/Question_01_(d)}{part
(d)} we found that, in order for \emph{p(x)} to have zero slope at
\emph{x = 0} and \emph{x = 2} and pass through the given points, the
coefficients $\mathbf{a} = s_1\mathbf{a}_1 + s_2\mathbf{a}_2$ would need
to satisfy

\[\begin{bmatrix}
-4 &1 \\ 
-2& 1\\ 
0& 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
s_1 \\ s_2
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}\]

How can we find the least square solution of the system
\emph{C\textbf{s} = \textbf{c}} above?

The least square solution \textbf{\emph{s}} satisfies

\[C^TC \mathbf s = C^T \mathbf c\]
